Posts.Content: I did not use a conversion chart. Go to Figure 1, B in link below for THC stratification by light, medium and heavy use (light, medium and heavy is among daily users) Heavy Cannabis Use Associated With Reduction in Activated and Inflammatory Immune Cell Frequencies in Antiretroviral Therapy–Treated Human Immunodeficiency Virus–Infected Individuals https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/66/12/1872/4869752
Posts.Title: Immunosupressive properties of cannabis.

Posts.Content: I am not sure of the meaning of the following study with respect to cancer. "heavy cannabis use was associated with lower frequencies of activated (HLA-DR+CD38+) CD4+ and CD8+ T cells compared to frequencies of these cells in non-cannabis-using individuals. This novel finding is important given that elevated levels of T-cell activation have been associated with lower CD4+ T-cell gains following ART [4] and with mortality in this population [29]. Thus, our work suggests that cannabinoids may have an immunological benefit in the context of HIV infection ' They identified daily cannabis uses and stratified them into light, medium and heavy usage by their blood THC levels. They didn't find any differences in their overall CD4+ and CD8+ frequency's but as mentioned above did find a difference in activated T cell frequency with heavy use suppressing activation. Heavy Cannabis Use Associated With Reduction in Activated and Inflammatory Immune Cell Frequencies in Antiretroviral Therapy–Treated Human Immunodeficiency Virus–Infected Individuals https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/66/12/1872/4869752
Posts.Title: Immunosupressive properties of cannabis.

Posts.Content: 50 mg in brownie would send me to the hospital. 5 to 7.5 was what I used during chemo (candy) and is what is listed on the package.
Posts.Title: Immunosupressive properties of cannabis.

Posts.Content: Interferon-a–Mediated Activation of T Cells from Healthy and HIV-Infected Individuals Is Suppressed by D9 -Tetrahydrocannabinol s "These results further support THC as being immune suppressive while identifying putatively beneficial aspects of cannabinoid-based therapies in HIV1 patients." https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Joseph_Henriquez/publicatio...
Posts.Title: Immunosupressive properties of cannabis.

Posts.Content: I haven't gone through all of the links but I think clinical studies of HIV patients or Hepatitis C patients are a better predictor of extent of immune suppression. Although the data on immune suppression is clear, I think practical impact is not that significant as dosing probably doesn't reach high enough levels. (unless consumption is outrageous) That applies as well for it's cancer fighting properties. For instance, "10 mg/kg body weight" is ~75x typical humane dose. "Cannabinoid-induced apoptosis in immune cells as a pathway to immunosuppression THC administration in vivo (10 mg/kg body weight) decreased the cellularity in the spleen and thymus,...." "150 mg/kg body weight" is ~ 1000x typical humane dose "CB2 cannabinoid receptor agonist, JWH-015, triggers apoptosis in immune cells: potential role for CB2-selective ligands as immunosuppressive agents....In vivo administration of JWH-015 (150 mg/kg body weight) inhibited the proliferation of splenocytes") 10uM is about 300x typical human dose. "investigated the effects of Aja on human peripheral blood T lymphocytes. This study showed that Aja reduced T cell proliferation by ∼75%, and induced apoptosis in a dose-dependent manner (at 1, 3 and 10 μM). " I
Posts.Title: Immunosupressive properties of cannabis.

Posts.Content: A Prospective Study of Humoral and Cellular Immune Responses to Hepatitis B Vaccination in Habitual Marijuana Smokers https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11481-018-9776-7 "Exposure to Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) in vitro and in animal models can significantly impair the differentiation, activation and function of dendritic cells, T cells and B cells. However, studies directly assessing the impact of marijuana smoking on human immunity are lacking..... While a larger cohort may be required to rule out a small suppressive effect, our findings do not suggest that habitual marijuana smoking exerts a major impact on the development of systemic immunity to hepatitis B vaccination."

Posts.Content: Hi onthemark 5 to 10 mg dose is what is listed on manufactures websites for edibles. (for a person). So if a average male weighs 75KG than 10mg/kg is about 75x dose.

Posts.Content: Recreational Drug Use and T Lymphocyte Subpopulations in HIV-uninfected and HIV-infected Men https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2691391/ "We found no clinically meaningful associations between use of marijuana, cocaine, poppers, or amphetamines and CD4 and CD8 T cell counts, percentages, or rates of change in either HIV-uninfected or -infected men."
